facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated November 17, 1961 of Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revisions 322, 323, 324, 611, 612 and 613 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated November 17, 1961, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision number. 322, 323, 324, 611, 612 and 613 of 1961.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on October 1, 1963 by SUBBA RAO J.

anchor.surface_text: P. Goyal, for the respondents  in Cr. A. Nos. 21-24 and 26 of 1962 - October 1, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO J.-

facts.text: Six appeals filed by certificates granted by Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO J.-These six appeals filed by certificates granted by the High Court of judicature at Allahabad raise the question

facts.text: Respondents alleged to be prostitutes carrying on trade in City of Kanpur.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts may be briefly stated. The respondents are alleged to be prostitutes carrying on their trade in the City of Kanpur.

facts.text: Sub-Inspector of Police, who is not a Special Police Officer, gave information to City Magistrate, Kanpur.

anchor.surface_text: On receiving information from the Sub- Inspector of Police, who is number a Special Police Officer, the City Magistrate, Kanpur, issued numberices to the respondents

facts.text: City Magistrate, Kanpur issued notices to respondents under s.20(1) of the Act to show cause why required to remove from places and prohibited from re-entering.

anchor.surface_text: On receiving information from the Sub- Inspector of Police, who is number a Special Police Officer, the City Magistrate, Kanpur, issued numberices to the respondents under s. 20 1  of the Act to show cause why they should number be required to remove themselves from the places where they were residing and be prohibited from re-entering them.

facts.text: Respondents received the notices.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents received the numberices and filed objections claiming that the proceedings were number legally maintainable.

facts.text: Respondents filed objections claiming proceedings not legally maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents received the numberices and filed objections claiming that the proceedings were number legally maintainable.

facts.text: City Magistrate repelled the objections.

anchor.surface_text: The learned City Magistrate repelled the said objections.

facts.text: Respondents filed revisions to Additional Sessions Judge Kanpur against Magistrate's orders, which were dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Against the orders of the Magistrate the respondents went up in revision to the Additional Sessions Judge Kanpur but the same were dismissed.

facts.text: Respondents preferred revisions to Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the respondents preferred revisions to the High Court of judicature at Allahabad

facts.text: Allahabad High Court allowed revision petitions and set aside proceedings in City Magistrate's court.

anchor.surface_text: and the said High Court allowed the revision petitions and set aside the proceedings pending against the respondents in the Court of the City Magistrate, Kanpur.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court held s.20 abridged fundamental rights under Art.14 and 19(1)(d) and (e).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that s. 20 of the Act abridged the fundamental rights of the respondents under Art. 14 and sub-cls.  d  and  e  of Art. 19 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: State obtained certificates for leave to appeal from High Court and preferred present appeals.

anchor.surface_text: After obtaining certificates for leave to appeal from the High Court, the present appeals have been preferred by the State.

facts.text: Suppression of Immoral Traffic in Women and Girls Act, 1956 (Act 104 of 1956).

facts.text: Act made in pursuance of International Convention signed at New York on May 9, 1950.

facts.text: Special Police Officer appointed under s.13 for each area specified by State Government.

anchor.surface_text: Section 13 of the Act says that there shall be for each area to be specified by the State Government in this behalf a special police officer appointed by or on behalf of that Government

facts.text: Appeals preferred by the State.

arguments.claim: Information under s.20 may come from any source, not limited to special police officer under s.13.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore, hold, giving the natural meaning to the expression on receiving information, that information may be from any source.

arguments.claim: Magistrate under s.20 acts as a court.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore, hold that in the circumstances the Magistrate must be held to be acting as a court. If the Magistrate is acting as a court, as we have held he is, it is obvious that be is subject to the revisional jurisdiction conferred under ss. 435 and 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

arguments.claim: s.20 does not infringe Art.14; reasonable classification between nuisance-causing prostitutes and others with rational relation to object of suppressing immoral traffic.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that s. 20 of the Act does not infringe Art. 14 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: s.20 imposes reasonable restrictions on Art.19(1)(d),(e) in interests of general public.

anchor.surface_text: The said restrictions placed upon them are certainly in the interests of the general public and, as the imposition of the restrictions is done through a judicial process on the basis of a clearly disclosed policy, the said restrictions are clearly reasonable.

arguments.claim: Decisions under other Acts do not guide vires of s.20.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether a particular provisions offends Art. 14 of the Constitution or not depends upon the provisions of the Act wherein that section appears. The decisions on other Acts do not afford any guidance to decide the Vires of s. 20 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: the said restrictions placed upon them are certainly in the interests of the general public and, as the imposition of the restrictions is done through a judicial process on the basis of a clearly disclosed policy, the said restrictions are clearly reasonable.

holdings.text: s. 20 of the Suppression of Immoral Traffic in Women and Girls Act, 1956 is constitutional

anchor.surface_text: These six appeals filed by certificates granted by the High Court of judicature at Allahabad raise the question of the vires of s. 20 of the Suppression of Immoral Traffic in Women and Girls Act, 1956  104 of 1956 , hereinafter called the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds against Art.14 (reasonable classification) and Art.19(1)(d),(e) (reasonable restrictions); clear policy, judicial procedure with checks via revision.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the Bombay High Court, in Begum v. State 1 bad to companysider the same question number before us. It held that the provisions of s. 20 of the Act would number be bit by Art. 14 of the Constitution, though it held that the provisions of s. 20 of the Act which enable a Magistrate to direct a prostitute to remove herself from the place where she is residing to a place without the local limits of his jurisdiction was an unresonable restriction upon the fundamental right guaranteed under Art. 19 1 d and e of the Constitution.

precedents.cited_proposition: provisions of s. 20 of the Act do not violate Article 14 but the deportation provision imposes unreasonable restriction under Article 19(1)(d) and (e)

precedents.citation: Shama Bai v. State of U. P.  2

anchor.surface_text: In Shama Bai v. State of U. P.  2 , Sabai J., though he dismissed the writ petition without giving numberice to the other party, made some observations indicating his view that the said provision prima facie offends Art. 14 of the Constitution. For the reasons already stated by us, we do number agree with this view.

precedents.case_name: Shama Bai v. State of U. P.
precedents.cited_proposition: s. 20 of the Act prima facie offends Article 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench of the Bombay High Court in Begum v. State 1  numberdoubt held that the portion of s. 20 of the Act which enables the Magistrate to direct a prostitute to remove herself from the place where she is living to a place without the local limits of his jurisdiction unreasonably encroaches upon the fundamental right guaranteed under Art. 19 1 d and e of the Constitution and is, therefore, invalid. For the aforesaid reasons, we cannot agree with this view.

precedents.cited_proposition: portion of s. 20 enabling deportation outside jurisdiction unreasonably encroaches on Article 19(1)(d) and (e)

precedents.citation: Chintaman Rao v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 1

anchor.surface_text: Mahajan J., as he then was, speaking for the Court in Chintaman Rao v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 1  succinctly defined the expression reasonable restrictions thus The- phrase reasonable restriction companynotes the limitation imposed on a person in enjoyment of the right should number be arbitrary or of an excessive nature, beyond what is required in the interests of the public.

precedents.case_name: Chintaman Rao v. The State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: definition of reasonable restrictions: limitation should not be arbitrary or excessive beyond what is required in public interest; implies intelligent care and deliberation
precedents.cited_holding: The phrase 'reasonable restriction' connotes that the limitation imposed on a person in enjoyment of the right should not be arbitrary or of an excessive nature, beyond what is required in the interests of the public.

precedents.citation: The State of Madras v. V. G. Row 2

anchor.surface_text: A fairly exhaustive test to ascertain the reasonableness of a provision is given by Patanjali Sastri C.J. in The State of Madras v. V. G. Row 2 . Therein the learned Chief justice observed thus It is important in this companytext to bear in mind that the test of reasonableness, wherever prescribed  should be applied to each individual statute impugned, and numberabstract standard, or general pattern, of reasonableness can be laid down as applicable to all cases.

precedents.case_name: The State of Madras v. V. G. Row
precedents.cited_proposition: test of reasonableness of restrictions: nature of right, purpose of restriction, extent of evil, disproportion, prevailing conditions
precedents.cited_holding: the test of reasonableness... should be applied to each individual statute impugned... The nature of the right alleged to have been infringed, the underlying purpose of the restrictions imposed, the extent and urgency of the evil sought to be remedied thereby, the disproportion of the imposition, the prevailing conditions at the time, should all enter into the judicial verdict.
